column1: Will there be 12 or more Chapter 9 municipal bankruptcy filings in 2020?
column6: ['Finance', 'Economic Policy', 'US Politics']

Can't see any news in the comments of a surge of Chapter 9's. As the number of chapter 9s which would have to take place in the last quarter for this to come true would be, or close to, unprecedented I think it would have been covered in the news. So going down to zero chance for the last days of the year.
There could be a bankruptcy surge in 2021.

Going down a bit more. Should have been some news (in general and here) if there was several chapter 9s being filed. As previously noted the number of chapter 9s for the period Oct 2019-Sep 2020 was 4 which means there has to be a at least 8 (probably more) chapter 9s in the last quarter for this to come true.
mark to market, 4 YTD, before year-end w/ holidays seems unlikely
Biden admin will want to support - Can't file for Ch9 if you have not exhausted all options
Rolling 12 month on sept report has 4 filings, so feels very unlikely now.
updating for passage of time, 6 weeks left

/No stimulus/federal aid before election /Transition is slow /Transition is uncertain, as the election will remain under scrutiny for a while (recounts, law suits) and the target for attempted delegitimization, thus federal aid likely not before February 2021 /Balance of Power (House vs Senate) uncertain: Senate Republicans could continue to block important federal legislation in order to sabotage the incoming government of 46 POTUS and make it appear failing /Spending remains elevated /risk of "accidental default" for technical reasons (deadline, administrative failure,...) higher than on average due to political turmoil and elevated workload within municipalities (election year, health crisis, economic crisis, education crisis, risk of key faculty on sick leave at crucial times due to virus exposure,...)
Given last year was a relatively good financial year, it'd seem a doubling in Chapter 12 filing seems double the likelihood versus not

I am lowering my prediction after seeing the quarter ending Sept. 30 showing a total of 4 Chp. 9 filings thus far this calendar year. There will likely still be fallout as a result of the pandemic but will probably not be fully seen until 2021.

If I read the numbers correctly there has been 4 Chapter 9 filings in the period Oct 2019-Sep 2020.[1] If I'm reading the data correctly it means there will have to be at least 8 chapter 9 filings in the last quarter of this year. There is a high probability I'm misunderstanding the data, but as that is what I have to go on I'm lowering my prediction of this happening. If someone can correct my reading or reaffirm it I would be grateful.
Expected "normalization" of politics during POTUS's quarantine?

The Fed access lending is helping to keep many on the edge of bankruptcy but not filling. Strategically, a municipality that does not borrow the max possible from the Fed lending facility and then does not files for bankruptcy is not acting on the best interest of its citizens given the present situation. No more or less what corporations are doing now.

There have been 2 Chapter 9 filings since April 2020, as per Courts stats, (to be used to determine outcome, as per Q above). All else appears to be speculative nonsense. https://www.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/data_tables/bf_f2.1_0630.2020.pdf

Many (maybe most; it's been a long time since I needed to know this) US municipalities use the calendar year as their fiscal year, so their budgets must be in place by 31 December. That means they will confront the reality of their '21 budgets starting in the next few weeks, although many will put off the final stage (panicky negotiations and wholesale fudging) until early November.

Going down slightly since the number of bankruptcies seem pretty stable. For the year 30 June 2019- 30 June 2020 the number of chapter 9 was six.[1] Nothing out of the ordinary seem to be happening at the moment. Will watch out for the numbers that will be released for the period 30 Sept 2019-30 Sept 2020.[2]
Federal Reserve via the Main Street Lending program will prevent bankruptcy filings above 12

As it seems to be part of the T. re-election campaign to spread chaos among the US municipalities, to create violence, capital crime and the appearance of the situation out of control, in order to maintain their framing of federal agents and involvement was necessary to "maintain law and order", a typical Republican claim, payments will be on hold intentionally for a while still. It may be true that citizens who are afraid are easier to rule, since they tend to be looking for strongmen. However, creating a problem that is there for its own purpose of one party and the incumbent pretending to have problem solving competencies is just ridiculous, most intelligent voters will see through this scheme. However, even intelligent voters may rightly be afraid of the future, especially when it comes to the very near domestic future in the next half year, and election procedures. Also however, Republican voter base mainly recruits from white rural non-college educated voters, so the strategy may just work as planned and send a few but significant municipalities over the brink to "see what happens", before finally any money will be released.
Ticking up slightly higher - had been surprised a deal in congress hadn't been concluded
Back to the start ...
Any further delay in federal fiscal stimulus and municipal finance assistance could rush at least a few very weak, mostly smaller and/or rural municipalities into Chapter 9 bankruptcy filing.
Guess up to 3 x
I lack conviction. Following the crowd.
Revised forecast, taking into consideration evidence provided by crowd.
Average over the past decade is 6 per year, therefore there is a likelihood that this year will see a larger than average number of Chapter 9 filings.
6 filings on June report, assuming I’m looking at the right data.
Fed's Municipal Liquidity Facility should provide some cushion.
Currently at 3 chapter 9 filings for 2020. Seems unlikely to reach 12, but you know, 2020 is a crazy year, so anything could happen.

Having thoroughly read the actions and definitions [1], that both necessitate and grant Chapter 9 proceedings, it appears an unlikely event that 12 such instances should occur in this timeframe (or, rather, 6 more); esp. given historical data and requisite contexts...

Q2 F-5A was posted to uscourts.gov today. The news is mostly expected, there have been 4 Chapter 9 bankruptcies so far in 2020. In addition to the previous 3 identified (Jack County, TX, Douglas County, NE and Jefferson County, AL) there was a second bankruptcy in Jack County, TX. In line with previous analysis, in order to reach 12 municipal bankruptcies, there will need to be 8 more this year. 8 bankruptcies in 6 months would be an extremely high rate. Since my last forecast, we also have a lot more certainty in our data, as we have the official totals through July 1. Using historic data, we can adjust our estimates down and be more confident in our prediction.
Latest filings show no new Chapter 9 bankruptcies in Q2. [1] Consquently cutting forecast by 5 percent.
Base rate: 8.3 bankruptcies on average over last 20 years
updating to reflect likely lag of impact from recession to municpal filings, as well as potential for federal funds to backstop state/local governments

Staying the course but feel strenghtened in this: "Fox News is told Republicans are looking at $100 billion of the $1 trillion to go to state and local governments" - a sign that there are still carrots being dangled in front of lower governments - muddying the water whether it's 100% necessary to go through CH9 pains
As economies improve and additional stimulus is available the likelihood is decreasing

Since 1980 there has been an average of 8.2 municipal bankruptcies per year. Obviously, 2020 is anything but a typical year. Although it is not official yet, we are likely in a recession in the United States (we will not know for certain until GDP estimates of the past 6 months are finalized). 2020 is also an election year, which likely has a small impact on the number of municipal bankruptcies, as local election calendars are not overly correlated with the timing of national elections.

Let’s reread the question! There were 6 filings in the 12 months to March 2020. Compared to December when there were also 6 in the last 12 months this suggested there have already been 3 filings during 2020. Higher probability of getting to 12. Bankruptcies have a lag time on them and coivd19 kicked off in March 2020. Lower probability of getting to 12. 12 in 2020 is double the current rolling 12 month number. Lower probability of getting 12. Bankruptcies might be seen as an easier way out of a tough spot with covid19. Higher probability of getting to 12. Keeping forecast high, but lower than my previous forecast. Need to see the June returns, which should be published soon.
Going from 40% to 25%.
Dialing down yet again... then holding steady til late fall unless the news changes

Prior: there have been 167 bankruptcies 2000-2019, averaging 8.35 per year, and with 4 years surpassing 12, so my prior will be 20%. https://www.statista.com/statistics/1118479/bankruptcy-filings-us-chapter-9-municipality/

12 happened in 2009, 3 has happened so far, expect more financial pressure with second COVID resurgence but still think it is rather unlikely that 12 will be surpassed especially with strong fiscal and monetary policy.

https://www.usmayors.org/issues/covid-19/fiscal-pain-tracker/ Going back down. After reading what each city is doing it is mostly layoffs. I see they expect problems extending into next year but are coping so far this year. If the Feds give more to cities and states then this for sure will not happen.
Hedging toward consensus

Total radio silence in terms of news chatter re: add'l Chapter 9 filings. Consistent with prior rationale, I count only two filings so far this year. (Three if Faith Community Health’s second filing [1] counts as such, or whether it is counted as a reinstatement of their original February filing...I'm unclear how that will be reported.)

https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/municipal-bankruptcy-avoiding-and-using-57200/ " while bankruptcy protection may be necessary to buy time to consummate such a financing and delay disruptive collections efforts or the forced liquidation of collateral, all efforts should be made to convince creditors to be patient and not to cause the municipality to incur the significant costs associated with a bankruptcy filing"
Dialing down with the passage of time

Ok in 2009 there were 12. It does not appear federal funds are yet in the offing for cities and states. Less work, less spending means less tax revenue so more likely. https://www.npr.org/2020/06/08/868982984/much-of-the-stimulus-aid-sent-to-states-hasnt-gone-where-it-s-needed-most
Increasing slightly due to dynamics of second surge. Don't think it changes things materially...but some increase is certainly due. Up 3% for now.

Last time was 2009 with 12. Unemployment then was 9.9. It is projected to be 9.3 in December in US. Close call. If Congress does not give money to States and Cities I will raise. If they do then lower. Leaving for now.

I count two or three Chapter 9s so far this year (three if Faith Community Health’s second filing [1] counts as such, or whether it is counted as a reinstatement of their original February filing). Anyone tracking more that I’m missing?
Given the US stimulus package along with municipal cuts I dont see 12 or more.
If there were 6 last year, there will definitely be 12 this year because of increased costs and lost revenue for munis.

I agree with very low chance given fiscal year end differences per municipality and that there have been 2 filings so far as of 3/20. Only 2 months later, states have started to open up so municipal revenues will not drop further from there. I suspect despite rising cases, many counties/states will have very high threshold to close down again. Less stomach for economic hardship than full hospitals at the politician level (rightly or wrongly)
Muni revenue will be decimated
FED has confirmed to shoot in liquidity and buy even larger sums of municipal bonds if market conditions require it. Still not unlikely, for a number of smaller non-market financed municipalities.

https://www.governing.com/gov-data/municipal-cities-counties-bankruptcies-and-defaults.html https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/municipalities-revenue-crunches-and-19646/ Mitch McConnell probably wants to shrink government but he is running for re-election and Kentucky will help. https://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/politics/2020/04/29/kentucky-congressman-says-relief-states-cities-virtually-certain/3044926001/ There is that and bankruptcy is rare so lowering backdown.

At the municipal and state level you need to get your budget rundown before you can start to file for propections and defaults, most of the budgets are calendar dated. So, if Congress does not act before the year, expect 2021 to be a scary one, for now is all screaming and yelling for $$, but so far nothing seems to persuade Mitch and his crowd.
Dialing down a touch with further passage of time. Original logic below...

The year is half over already, and filings haven't been that big. Also, there will be a lag between the beginning of the recession in March and drop in municipal revenue. I expect any filings for bankruptcy to be mostly in 2021.
Am confident of the devastating impact from Covid 19
Likely toss will happen, however, many municipalities have successfully cut back and taken advantage of federal programs, so there is a strong possibility they can avoid BK.

Municipality leaders made decisions that hurt their tax collections while practicing totalitarian shut downs to save lives instead of a balanced rational process weighing economics, health and freedom. Taxing their way out is not an option for many of the municipalities.
I think there will be many, but I see them happening at a later date. They will try other actions first, including asking for Federal help, which will not be resolved with this Congress.
Currently there is no federal funding going to the states to offset covid response expenses.

At this time there are costs due to social unrest, disrupted working pattern, extra work for certain municipal employees and huge financial hardship for people meaning there will be less taxes. On top of this many places were already over extended. Appetite or availability of funds to help bail out the worst offenders will also diminish. The first fallers might get lucky, but later on the line in the sand will get more defined. Therefore it’s very likely to have a lot of bankruptcies. Also the increase in threshold from 6 in a normal year to 9 is not that large so could be easy to pass in this weird year.
The coming depression is going to be far harder than most are thinking. Read some history. This is not a hard call.
Historically there have been very few. The coronavirus and subsequent drain on municipalities have really drained many municipalities of their funds.
The unlikelihood that the federal government will bailout states. This will force local municipalities to restructure under chapter 9.
Unless there is a bailout of the states then bankruptcies will result. Because this bailout has been clouded by politics, unfortunately, many states will suffer.

Over 2,000 cities were already forecasting budget shortfalls of a combined $360 billion as of mid-May. Lawmakers in Washington are increasingly weary of piling on to the already exorbitant U.S. debt load, including Democrats.
A lot of businesses are going to go under this year due to poor government planning and Covid 19 lockdown orders.
Hospitals lost a giant portion of their profit generation from COVID and most of them were running near or at break even to begin with.
With the global impact of the Covid virus and now the unrest, it seems very likely many more places of business will file for bankruptcy in the near future.

I guess the crowd consensus has become unreliable. Situation still very uncertain. Looks like we have a third bankruptcy this year: “The Vallejo City Council voted overwhelmingly on April 6 for the city to file for Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection” www.kron4.com/news/bay-area/vallejo-city-council-to-release-police-department-audit-findings-at-special-meeting/amp/ Some additional info about hospital bankruptcy: “The hospitals that have filed for bankruptcy this year, which are part of the health systems listed below, have not cited the pandemic as a factor that pushed them into bankruptcy.” https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/finance/29-hospital-bankruptcies-in-2020.html “When forced by financial circumstances, hospitals usually seek relief in bankruptcy by filing under chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code” “the health-care industry is suffering a historic collapse in business” “In states so authorizing, hospitals which constitute municipalities also may seek relief under chapter 9 of the Bankruptcy Code; however, most states – including Indiana and Illinois - currently do not allow municipalities to file bankruptcy.” https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=c29c3810-5205-42df-b576-6445a09def4f https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/finance/what-does-chapter-9-bankruptcy-mean-for-public-hospitals.html
I think most trouble businesses will at least limp into 2021
Municipalities will wait until Jan 1, 2021.
It has been much higher in prior years and Covid is going to hurt.
Without help from the federal government, they will need to file for bankruptcy.
The loss of tax revenue will be to great to recover from the shutdowns.
Major impact to public institutions.
Not likely this early. The federal govt won’t allow this
Municipalities are screwed and no one cares.

I like to point to the 580K job lost in the May job report. That's an indicator of a tight budgetary prospect for governments. Loss of revenue because of COVID-19 can not be recovered in any form other than direct money in the form of Federal Fiscal policy. It is very likely that compared to 2019 (six) we would reach twice that (12) bankruptcies year. The only thing that can change this is political will that is very unlikely to come to fruition this year and without a slew of bankruptcies as evidence of the worsening problem. With no grime outlook, there won't be any political attention to this problem.

I don't believe there is much of an incentive in an election year to let a large number of local governments fail. Still, a small number of badly administered local government might well fail, and, depending on the course of the pandemic over the next several months, others might follow in 2021.

6 municipalities declared bankruptcy last year, when the economy was still in good standing. This year, with a pandemic-induced recession, any municipality that was on the brink of financial issues will suffer from diminished incomes. It seems highly likely therefore that we should see at least double the number of last year's bankruptcy filings.
I agree with Leonardthethird's analysis offered below and having included some of my own thoughts afterwards.
According to comments there have been two this far this year which I adjust to.

Original logic below. Adjusting downward simply due to elapsed time without any signal suggesting that probability of "Yes" is increasing. Still appear to have been only 2 Chapter 9s so far in 2020. No news reports suggesting any others are imminent at this time.
Finacial crisis - and a lack of collative cohesiveness at senior level sto address with finacial support

To my knowledge, there've been two Chapter 9 bankruptcy filings this year: Faith Community Health System and the City of Fairfield. Need to check after August, the effect of coronacrisis should be clear by then. As of now it's safe to stay at 50-50. Undecided as of now. I'm not sure about the lag involved with filing bankruptcies. Apart from that I believe that there'll be more than 12 municipal bankruptcy filings in 2020.
Forgot to raise. See my prior comments.

2006 5 2007 6 2008 4 2009 12 2010 6 2011 13 1st half 2012 7 The downturn in the economy 2008-2011 is comparable to now. Many small towns don’t have the budgets to cover emergency needs. In my rather prosperous town they are going to have layoffs and pay roll backs for government workers. Without Federal Aid to States that they can pass to cities there is no way they are going all make it. Maybe because of 2008 cities are better prepared but the cost here in terms of no taxes is unprecedented. I am raising this slightly a little above 50%.
Adjusting down closer to the consensus based on other forecasters' research.

leonardthethird makes a lot of sense. Especially about the lag time. Lowering. Note to any followers: in the past I took way less questions. It is easier to be a SuperForecaster if you limit yourself from 50-75 questions in a season. Allows more time to drill down like checking the balance sheets of every schedule III airline to see likelihood of bankruptcy. Just having fun learning here.

Longterm base rate quite low...didn’t count, but graph looks like around 10%. Reinforcing a number in that range are the numbers from the most recent recession: first spike trailed by two years, with peak four years following beginning of recession. This seems like a strong signal that a spike of magnitude in question is very unlikely this year.

I'm just getting into my first forecasts on the GJ site, and I really appreciate all the links and comments provided by others. They give me a good place to start. After digesting it to the extent that I'm able to right now, I'm starting at the low end. I think the federal govt may see it in its best interest to prevent bankruptcies to the greatest extent possible in order to avoid negative economic news as we head towards the 2020 elections.
Adjusting to the crowd and per research below.

Over the last 20 years, the base rate for this (>12 municipal bankruptcy filings) has been 10%. Around the 2007/2008 recession, the highest point was 10 bankruptcies in 2009, indicating a lag. So a priori, despite the bad situation, we wouldn't expect bankruptcies to turn up this year. But maybe the loss in revenue is so great that they'll be forced to act sooner. In 2009, this sheet (https://www2.census.gov/govs/pubs/state_loc_gov/state_loc_gov_2009.pdf) indicates that local government revenues minus expenditures summed for a shortfall of $200 billion. Assuming the current shortfall will be broadly similar, then 3/4 of the shortfall will be mitigated by the government's stimulus. In addition, it's not clear that property values will fall as they did during the 08 recession, and property taxes make up a significant portion of municipal revenue: in 2009 they constituted 3/4 of all municipal tax revenue. Still, the situation is unusual, so I inflate my estimate form 10% to 25%.

- Last peak in bankruptcies was 2009 - 2014, predominantly by special purpose districts (healthcare a major one). Right after 2008 housing crash. - There tends to be a lag in bankruptcy filings (1 - 2 years after an event.) Took about 9 months after 2008 market crash for filings to begin. I would suspect more in 2021/2022 than 2020 - Some states require their authorization for a bankruptcy filing - The states that allow municipal bankruptcy without state approval are the larger populated states. Perhaps this increases likelihood of more filings this year - These bankruptcy filings were predominantly in states where municipalities do not need state authorization - One so far this year - Fairfield in AL. Will others be influences to follow suit or will local governments hate the thought? Election year.... - Only 7 months left in 2020, so tempering likelihood of reaching 12 bankruptcies but wary that healthcare special districts tends to be the most impacted - I believe Feds will attempt to support favored cities from bankruptcy - a total mix of red state/blue state in the 2010 - 2014 bankruptcies
The worst year for Chapter 9 filings were 2011 and 2009 (with 13 and 12 filings respectively).
FED support

Base rate appears to be ~20% according to the table in the MuniNet source. However, I'm not sure how much the base rate tells us since the economic downturn that's gonna happen this year hasn't happened in the past century. I think the 1990-1991 recession is among the best indicators for what could happen this time (since that also started early in the year), which implies that the probability is a lot higher than 20%.

Needs more research. https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/04/coronavirus-cities-bankruptcy/609169/ https://www.forbes.com/sites/investor/2020/05/19/forewarned-is-forearmed-tips-and-pointers-for-municipal-bond-workouts/

Only happened 4 times in last 10 years (Statista) - but reducing base rate because - seems to be a lag (2009 had 12 filings, '08 only 4) - bankrupting municipalities in election year is bad press - CoV 19 is externality therefore expecting a lot more federal & state relief / negotiation to take place before biting the bullet
Kneejerk baseline... will reevaluate and reconsider with more research.
